text: today on the caucus as Newt Gingrich
officially enters the race for president
we take a closer look columnist Matt by
answers reader questions about his
nascent campaign and Katherine QC Lee
who covered mr. Gingrich to the 1990s
reflects on the politician she remembers
I do believe that we have an
extraordinarily fundamental choice to
make about the very future of this
country my column about Newt Gingrich
yesterday and his presidential campaign
brought a huge array of responses this
was about his sense of himself in
history and why he believes himself to
be a very consequential player in the
history of his time and therefore the
viable candidate for president and we
wanted to address a few of the questions
today the first one I picked here is
from Perry m in st. Louis Perri
commented on line he said do we need
another old guy to run for GOP president
again how many times do we need to vote
for white-haired dolts who think it's my
turn I don't know if I'd call Newt
Gingrich a white-haired dolt actually
but I do think there's a very valid
point here about generation if you look
at the Republican field as it's
beginning to shape up there was a first
debate last week and maybe the only top
tier candidate in that stage might have
been Tim Pawlenty the governor of
Minnesota but then look at the other
potential talk to your candidates let's
say Mitt Romney perhaps Jon Huntsman the
former governor of Utah perhaps mitch
Daniels the sitting governor of Indiana
all of them would turn a generational
corner for Republicans the same corner
the Democrats effectively turned when
they nominated Barack Obama 2008
Gingrich on the other hand would be 69
when he took the oath of office he's
considerably older than all these guys
and I do think it raises an important
question for Republican voters about
whether the party needs to move along
generationally or whether perhaps
there's something reassuring about a
candidate who takes them back to a time
where they felt the country was on a
better track now this one comes from
facebook is richer Halpert jr. i hope i
pronounced that right Richard says how
can a serial adulterer and a lapsed
evangelical run on a quote-unquote
family values platform and the reason
I've chosen this one is because it's in
so many of the comments I would say a
dominant theme of the mail I got two is
about Newt Gingrich's adultery and his
past mayor
are just his personal transgressions now
I get that there's an issue here of
hypocrisy because of course speaker
Gingrich is one of the people who led
the impeachment process against Bill
Clinton but here's the thing i just
don't really care about candidates sex
lives and personal lives and marriages
and i think voters care less and less
now you can go to like a million blogs
and they'll tell talk all about his past
transgressions in his personal life and
whether it matters to voters and all of
that you're just not really going to
find it in my work now the final thing I
want to address is Dave in New Jersey
Dave commented on line of the piece and
he said never was a fan of Newt but to
all those who are discounting his
chances remember one thing who would
have thought in 2007 that a black junior
senator from Illinois would be President
the following year Dave I commend you
because I think this is a really
excellent point for all of us to
remember covering it and reading about
inches we have no idea at this point of
the process who is a viable candidate
and who isn't with the possible
exception of Donald Trump i would say
Donald Trump is probably not going to
get the Republican nomination and
actually herb kane he's going to lose
too but it's a good place I came to
Washington in 1994 with the times at
that point Newt was already in Congress
and it was clear he was setting a
national agenda campaigning to be not
just speaker but sort of leader of the
party we have a contract with america we
had 330 candidates signed the contract
we put it in TV Guide as a full-page ad
he was better at that at sort of the
outside oppositional role then in the
role of actually governing one of those
stories that I think really illustrates
a lot about newts temperament was after
the government shutdown in the mid 90s
he told a story it came to a print
breakfast one morning and he suddenly
told us that he was had really been
missed
on an overseas trip with President
Clinton on Air Force One he had been
relegated to the back of the plane he
had to come up the back steps he had
expected the president to use this time
to negotiate with him about the budget
and the president wasn't wasn't
interested and Newt said essentially
that he shut down the government because
he was miffed at being relegated to the
back of the plane the famous picture
that came out of this was the Daily News
that then had a big picture of him in
diapers saying cry baby I don't think it
was necessarily his doing that was a
mistake I think he does have a very
grandiose sense of himself he sees
himself in this great tradition of
political history you know is one of the
greats stalking the earth he did kind of
go off into the wilderness and that's
what's interesting now is that his last
campaign was in 98 so this is quite a
while to kind of come back on the scene
not having been in an even a competitive
race for so many years
you
